awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mesoscopic Defect Field Interactions in Materials with High Number Density of Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Deformation behavior of crystalline materials is highly complex, owing to a hierarchy of length scales that describes their structural makeup. Interfaces link distinct crystal structures or material phases at these various length scales. The interactions of crystalline defects with interfaces are chiefly responsible for the emergent material behavior at the application scale. The collective interactions of defects and interfaces through multiple scales up to the higher scale of everyday applications have been extremely challenging to resolve experimentally and have also not been captured using computer simulations to the desired sophistication. This is a significant obstacle to the understanding of the behavior of complex materials, where high density of specific interfaces is instrumental in achieving superior functional and/or mechanical properties. This research aims to address this challenge through the study of superlattices and metamaterials by exploiting and further advancing an atomistic-to-continuum scale method. It is expected that this research will significantly promote the fields of mechanics of materials and computational materials science, with commensurate impact on the rapidly developing field of computational materials design, which will advance national health, prosperity, and welfare. This work is also expected to have substantial broader impact through training of undergraduate students in high-performance computing, graduate curriculum enhancements, and dissemination of codes to the wider community. The project will also reach out to engage students from underrepresented groups.

Superlattices and metamaterials represent two emerging material systems that derive their exceptional properties from structure rather than composition. With their well-ordered periodic interfaces and structure, superlattices and metamaterials provide model systems amenable to systematic study of the collective role of interfaces on evolving defect structures. The goal of this collaborative effort is to demonstrate the collective role of interfaces and defects on mechanical properties by studying this special class of material systems by using an advanced Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum (CAC) approach. It is expected that this research will identify the dominant deformation mechanisms as well as the key structural variables that control the materials behavior and the underlying mechanisms, explore the critical length scale or structural parameters at which the materials exhibit a transition from ductile to brittle behavior, and investigate the fundamental phenomena that control the plastic flow and fracture behaviors in these material systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Results of this study have led to publication of 15 journal articles, and we are also currently writing a few manuscripts.   Significant results are as follows:

(1) Reformulated the CAC conservation equations to enable atomic-scale field representation of transport processes. These conservation equations hold instantaneously in the distributional sense, with which heat flux and stress are no longer required to be continuous, thereby addressing the question on whether continuum quantities such as stress still exists at the atomic length and time scale, while enabling a mathematically rigorous solution to highly nonequilibrium transport problems.

(2) Developed a massively parallel algorithm, which enables CAC to become one of the first open-sourced methods to successfully solve a system with O(N/P) scaling when the solution involves multiple scales of finite elements, discrete particles, and their interaction through non-local forces.

(3) Implemented the CAC formulation in LAMMPS codebase, which makes CAC easily accessible by the computational science community in the world.

(4) Reproduced the failure patterns of Si micropillars under compression that has been widely observed in experiments, thereby demonstarting the capability of the CAC method in simulation of the deformation and failure of mesoscale structures.

(5) Identified the mechanism for the formation of the central cracks in Si micropillars as a result of dislocations piling ups and intersection of slip bands and illustrated the mechanisms underlying the size-dependent ductile-to-brittle transition.

(6) Identified the type, density, and structure of defects associated with PbTe/PbSe, Si/Ge, GaN/AlN phase interfaces, and their role in mechanical and thermal transport properties of the heterostructures, adding mechanistic understanding and valuable data for the defect structure and dynamics in  semiconductor multilayers.

(7) Illustrated and quantified two mechanisms for phonon-dislocation interaction: (1) phonon scattering by the strain field of stationary dislocations, and (2) phonon scattering by dislocations that vibrate via the local modes of the dislocation networks; the latter, leads to resonant phonon-dislocation interaction, which is manifested as local maxima of out-of-phase vibration of the atoms on the two sides of the slip plane, leading to local minima of the energy transmission in the heterostructure. This work has also demonstrated, for the first time, the collective motion of dislocations in dislocation networks under ultrafast phonon pulses.

(8) Obtained, for the first time, the multiscale details of the transient processes of phonon scattering and transmission in periodically structured Si phononic crystals, providing a clear picture of the nature of phonon transport and its dependence on the structural parameters, thereby making an important step forward in establishing a fundamental understanding of wave dynamics in periodically structured metamaterials.  It also adds important data and new knowledge that are fundamental to existing meso- and macro-scale computational methods, as they are needed as the basic input in these methods.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Youping Chen

Images (1 of )
  • Snapshots of temperature in a Si phononic crystal that contains ~16 billion atoms in response to heat pulses with different central wavelength, simulated by CAC with 480K finite elements, showing ballistic and diffusive phonon transport, where p=34.8nm is the period of the phononic crystal.
    Yang Li, Adrian Diaz, Xiang Chen, David McDowell, Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    Wave dynamics in periodically structured Si phononic crystals simulated using CAC
  • Temperature propagation in a (a-d) Si single crystal and (e-h) a Si phononic crystal, excited by a phonon heat pulse obeying the Bose-Einstein phonon distribution, showing the ballistic phonon transport in the Si single crystal and the diffusive phonon transport in the phononic crystal.
    Yang Li, Adrian Diaz, Xiang Chen, David McDowell, Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    A comparison between temperature propagation in a Si single crystal and that in a Si phononic crystal with a heater in the center
  • Non-uniform Fourier transform of the displacement responses of a Si phononic crystal to phonon heat pulses, showing various vibrational modes that are excited, including the internal-surface-related local modes. The Brillouin zone boundaries are indicated by the dash lines.
    Yang Li, Adrian Diaz, Xiang Chen, David McDowell, Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    Vibrational modes in a Si phononic crystal
  • The atomic structure of the PbTe/PbSe (001) semi-coherent interface at different temperatures, obtained by CAC simulations, showing the dislocation networks at the interface. The inset is a scanning tunneling microscopy image of the PbTe/PbSe (001) semi-coherent interface at 300 K from experiments.
    Yang Li, Zexi Zheng, Adrian Diaz, Simon R. Phillpot, David L. McDowell and Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    Dislocation networks at the PbTe/PbSe phase interface
  • Time sequences of zoomed-in displacement contours during the propagation of (a) TA and (b) LA phonon pulses in a PbSe-PbTe heterostructure, showing phonon scattering by the misfit dislocation network at the interface. The interface is marked by the dashed line.
    Yang Li, Zexi Zheng, Adrian Diaz, Simon R. Phillpot, David L. McDowell and Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    Phonon scattering by interface misfit dislocations
  • Snapshots of the displacements of the PbSe and PbTe atoms at the interface during the propagation of (a) a TA phonon pulse and (b) a LA pulse, showing the out of phase (resonant) vibrations of the dislocation network under the TA pulse and the in-phase vibrations under the LA pulse.
    Yang Li, Zexi Zheng, Adrian Diaz, Simon R. Phillpot, David L. McDowell and Youping Chen
    Copyrighted
    Youping Chen
    Resonant interaction between phonons and a misfit dislocation network
